material-property-value-condition.content:
Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

Paragraph: The DCB solvent induced high performance photovoltaic devices due to the optimized interpenetrated network of the active film. The best devices of PDTP-BT and PDTP - DTBT show PCE of 1.64% and 2.37% , respectively. The polymer PDTP-DT2BT exhibits the highest PCE of 3.12% , ascribed to the largest J SC = 11.43 mA cm^-2 with a slightly lower V OC of 0.54 V and a slightly higher FF of 0.57 than the other polymers. The V OC values of the devices are around 0.5 V , suggesting that the addition of the thienyl units does not affect the main chain distortion. This coincides well with similar HOMO energy levels for the copolymers measured by CV. These results indicate that the PCEs of the photovoltaic devices based on PDTP-DT2BT : PC 70 BM were higher than those of PDTP - DTBT : PC 70 BM and PDTP-BT : PC 70 BM. Overall , it is an effective approach to improve the photovoltaic performance of PDTP - based copolymers by increasing the number of unsubstituted thienyl units along the copolymers backbone. Fig. 5 shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) plots of the devices based on three copolymer : PC 70 BM combinations under the illumination of monochromatic light. With the increase of thienyl spacers , the EQE response wavelengths show a blue shift , a similar tendency to the absorption spectra , but the EQE peak values were higher in PDTP-DT2BT ( 58% ) compared to PDTP-BT ( 23% ) or PDTP - DTBT ( 42% ). The shapes of the EQE curves of the devices in the range of 450-700 nm could be assigned to the stronger absorption of PC 70 BM . In conclusion , three low band gap D-A copolymers , based on the DTP donor and the BT acceptor , with different numbers of thienyl spacers along the backbone have been designed and synthesized. The thienyl spacer makes the absorption spectra peak blue - shift in the longer wavelength range and red - shift in the low wavelength range. Under 1.5 G^100 mW cm^-2 illumination , a best PCE of 3.12% for PDTP-DT2BT was recorded , with V OC = 0.48 V , J SC = 11.43 mA cm^-2 , and FF = 0.57. Although the best PCE is still not high enough for commercial use , our optimization by designing suitable molecular structures , selecting different solvents and changing other factors could provide useful information for further studies of the commercialized PSCs .

Let's think step by step.

1. DCB solvent induced high performance photovoltaic devices with an optimized interpenetrated network of the active film are discussed in the paragraph.
2. The best devices of PDTP-BT and PDTP - DTBT have Power Conversion Efficiencies (PCE) of 1.64% and 2.37%, respectively.
3. The polymer PDTP-DT2BT exhibits the highest PCE of 3.12%, with the highest short-circuit current density (J SC) of 11.43 mA cm^-2, a slightly lower open-circuit voltage (V OC) of 0.54 V, and a slightly higher fill factor (FF) of 0.57 compared to the other polymers.
4. The open-circuit voltage (V OC) values of the devices are around 0.5 V, suggesting that the addition of thienyl units does not affect the main chain distortion.
5. The polymer copolymers have similar highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy levels, as measured by cyclic voltammetry (CV).
6. The EQE peak values were higher in PDTP-DT2BT (58%) compared to PDTP-BT (23%) or PDTP - DTBT (42%).
7. The absorption spectra peak blue-shifts in the longer wavelength range and red-shifts in the low wavelength range with the increase of thienyl spacers.
8. Under 1.5 G^100 mW cm^-2 illumination, a best PCE of 3.12% for PDTP-DT2BT was recorded, with V OC = 0.48 V, J SC = 11.43 mA cm^-2, and FF = 0.57.

In summary, the paragraph discusses the properties of DCB solvent induced high performance photovoltaic devices with an optimized interpenetrated network of the active film. The best devices of PDTP-BT, PDTP - DTBT and PDTP-DT2BT have PCE of 1.64%, 2.37% and 3.12% respectively. The PDTP-DT2BT polymer exhibits the highest PCE of 3.12% with J SC of 11.43 mA cm^-2, V OC of 0.54 V and FF of 0.57. The EQE peak values were higher in PDTP-DT2BT (58%) compared to PDTP-BT (23%) or PDTP - DTBT (42%). The absorption spectra peak blue-shifts in the longer wavelength range and red-shifts in the low wavelength range with the increase of thienyl spacers.

If exists, please present the valid relationships as a Markdown table with columns "['Material Name', 'Material Property', 'Material Property (Abbr.)', 'Numerical Value', 'Condition']". Make sure the table items are from the original paragraph.

| Material Name | Material Property | Material Property (Abbr.) | Numerical Value | Condition |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| PDTP-BT | Power Conversion Efficiency (PCE) | - | 1.64% | - |
| PDTP - DTBT | Power Conversion Efficiency (PCE) | - | 2.37% | - |
| PDTP-DT2BT | Power Conversion Efficiency (PCE) | - | 3.12% | - |
| PDTP-DT2BT | Short-circuit current density (J SC) | mA cm^-2 | 11.43 | - |
| PDTP-DT2BT | Open-circuit voltage (V OC) | V | 0.54 | - |
| PDTP-DT2BT | Fill Factor (FF) | - | 0.57 | - |
| PDTP-BT | External Quantum Efficiency (EQE) peak value | % | 23 | - |
| PDTP - DTBT | External Quantum Efficiency (EQE) peak value | % | 42 | - |
| PDTP-DT2BT | External Quantum Efficiency (EQE) peak value | % | 58 | - |
| PDTP-DT2BT : PC 70 BM | Open-circuit voltage (V OC) | V | 0.48 | Under 1.5 G^100 mW cm^-2 illumination |

Note: The table is based on the information provided in the original paragraph.

It is worth noting that the values in the table are the best values obtained for each material, and the conditions under which they were measured are specified in the table.

It is also worth noting that the table only includes the properties of the materials that have numerical values associated with them, and does not include properties such as the absorption spectra shifting with the increase of thienyl spacers, as this is a qualitative observation rather than a numerical one.
